The trial lasts as long as it needs to. The trial's length depends on the number of witnesses and the questions asked them and the arguements ofthe lawyers and picking the jury and the court's instructions etc. This varies from case to case. In some cases a trial can go a day or two and in others weeks. It has no bearing on the length of the subsequent trial. A trial will last as long or as short as is necessary to get in all of the evidence and include all of the arguments of both sides. After a defendant is formally charged with a crime, the case proceeds to the criminal trial phase (unless the defendant pleads guilty). This begins with jury selection, in which the prosecuting attorney and defense counsel select a jury from the randomly selected jury pool through the process of elimination.

Jury cases cannot be tried during weeks designated as judge trial weeks and vice versa. Courts also set aside at least one day a week for the hearing of motions. Trials cannot be scheduled on days during which the court hears motions. Often, courts will break during the trial for a day to hear motions.
